cat: Plants used in traditional Chinese medicine
wiki.text:
{{taxobox |name = Liquorice |image = Illustration Glycyrrhiza glabra0.jpg
|regnum = Plantae |unranked_divisio = Angiosperms |unranked_classis = Eudicots
|unranked_ordo = Rosids |ordo = Fabales |familia = Fabaceae |subfamilia =
Faboideae |tribus = Galegeae |genus = [[Glycyrrhiza]] |species = 'G. glabra'
|binomial = Glycyrrhiza glabra |binomial_authority = L.<ref name="grin"> {{cite
web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?17820
|title=Glycyrrhiza glabra information from NPGS/GRIN |publisher=www.ars-grin.gov
|accessdate=6 March 2008 |last= |first= }} </ref> |synonyms = *Glycyrrhiza
glandulifera Waldst. & Kit.<ref name="grin"/>
|}}

'Liquorice' or 'licorice' ( or
)<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/licorice licorice.] Merriam-
Webster's Medical Dictionary, © 2007 Merriam-Webster, Inc.</ref> is the root of
'Glycyrrhiza glabra' from which a somewhat sweet flavor can be extracted. The
liquorice plant is a legume (related to beans and peas) that is native to
southern Europe and parts of Asia. It is not botanically related to anise, star
anise, or fennel, which are sources of similar flavouring compounds. The word
'liquorice'/'licorice' is derived (via the Old French licoresse), from the Greek
γλυκύρριζα (glukurrhiza), meaning "sweet root",<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.e-
du/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dgluku%2Frriza
γλυκύρριζα], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, A Greek-English Lexicon, on
Perseus</ref> from γλυκύς (glukus), "sweet"<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/h-
opper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dgluku%2Fs γλυκύς], Henry
George Liddell, Robert Scott, A Greek-English Lexicon, on Perseus</ref> + ῥίζα
(rhiza), "root",<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Ate-
xt%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dr%28i%2Fza ῥίζα], Henry George Liddell, Robert
Scott, A Greek-English Lexicon, on Perseus<</ref><ref>[http://oxforddictionarie-
s.com/view/entry/m_en_gb0474190#m_en_gb0474190 liquorice], on Oxford
Dictionaries</ref> the name provided by Dioscorides.<ref>[https://www.google.co-
m/search?q=Dioscorides%2C+who+names+the+plant+Glyrrhiza&btnG=Search+Books&tbm=b-
ks&tbo=1 google books] Maud Grieve, Manya Marshall - A modern herbal: the
medicinal, culinary, cosmetic and economic properties, cultivation and folk-lore
of herbs, grasses, fungi, shrubs, & trees with all their modern scientific uses,
Volume 2 Dover Publications, 1982 & Pharmacist's Guide to Medicinal Herbs Arthur
M. Presser Smart Publications, 1 Apr 2001 2012-05-19</ref>
wiki.title: Liquorice
